How Faithful is your Synthetic Data?
Sample-level Metrics for Evaluating and Auditing Generative Models

Ahmed M. Alaa â€ƒâ€ƒ Boris van Breugel â€ƒâ€ƒ Evgeny Saveliev â€ƒâ€ƒ Mihaela van der Schaar
Abstract

Devising domain- and model-agnostic evaluation metrics for generative models is an important and as yet unresolved problem.Â MostÂ existingÂ metrics, which were tailored solely to the image synthesis application, exhibit a limited capacity for diagnosing modes of failure of generative models across broader application domains.Â InÂ thisÂ paper, we introduce a 3-dimensional metric, (Î±ğ›¼\alpha-Precision, Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall, Authenticity), that characterizes the fidelity, diversity and generalization performance of any generative model in a wide variety of application domains. Our metric unifies statistical divergence measures with precision-recall analysis, enabling sample- and distribution-level diagnoses of model fidelity and diversity. We introduce generalization as an additional dimension for model performance that quantifies the extent to which a model copies training dataâ€”a crucial performance indicator when modeling sensitive and private data. The three metric components are interpretable probabilistic quantities, and can be estimated via sample-level binary classification. The sample-level nature of our metric inspires a novel use case which we call model auditing, wherein we judge the quality of individual samples generated by a (black-box) model, discarding low-quality samples and hence improving the overall model performance in a post-hoc manner.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Intuitively, it would seem that evaluating the likelihood function of a generative model is all it takes to assess its performance. As it turns out, the problem of evaluating generative models is far more complicated. This is not only because state-of-the-art models, such as Variational Autoencoders (VAE) (Kingma & Welling, 2013) and Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) (Goodfellow etÂ al., 2014), do not possess tractable likelihood functions, but also because the likelihood score itself is a flawed measure of performanceâ€”it scales badly in high dimensions, and it obscures distinct modes of model failure into a single uninterpretable score (Theis etÂ al., 2015). Absent domain-agnostic metrics, earlier work focused on crafting domain-specific scores, e.g., the Inception score in (Salimans etÂ al., 2016), with an exclusive emphasis on image data (Lucic etÂ al., 2018).

In this paper, we follow an alternative approach to evaluating generative models, where instead of assessing the generative distribution by looking at all synthetic samples collectively to compute likelihood or statistical divergence, we classify each sample individually as being of high or low quality. Our metric represents the performanceÂ ofÂ aÂ generative model as a point in a 3-dimensional spaceâ€”each dimension corresponds to a distinct quality of the model. These qualities are: Fidelity, Diversity and Generalization.Â FidelityÂ measuresÂ the quality of a modelâ€™s synthetic samples, and Diversity is the extent to which these samples cover the full variability of real samples, whereas Generalization quantifies theÂ extentÂ to which a model overfits (copies) trainingÂ data.Â All three measures are defined as binary conditions that can be inspected for individual samples in real and synthetic data.

Our main contribution is a refined precision-recall analysis of the Fidelity and Diversity performance of generative models that is grounded in the notion of minimum volume sets (Scott & Nowak, 2006). More precisely,Â weÂ introduceÂ the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-Precision and Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall as generalizations of the standard precision and recall metrics introduced in (Sajjadi etÂ al., 2018) to quantify model Fidelity and Diversity, respectively. Our proposed metrics inspect modelÂ performanceÂ withinÂ different density level sets for real and synthetic distributions, which enables more detailed diagnostics of the failure modes of generative models. In addition, we introduce the Authenticity metric to quantify Generalization, i.e., theÂ likelihoodÂ of a synthetic sample being copied from trainingÂ data,Â usingÂ a formal hypothesis test for data copying.Â ThisÂ additionalÂ evaluation dimension helps differentiate between models that truly â€œinventâ€ new samples and ones that generate ostensibly high-quality data by memorizing training samples.

How is our metric different? To highlight the qualities of synthetic data captured by our metric, we firstÂ provideÂ anÂ informal definition of its components. Our proposed precision-recall analysis operates on Î±ğ›¼\alpha- and Î²ğ›½\beta-minimum volume sets of the data distributionsâ€”that is, we assume that a fraction 1âˆ’Î±1ğ›¼1-\alpha (or 1âˆ’Î²1ğ›½1-\beta) of the real (and synthetic)Â dataÂ are â€œoutliersâ€, and Î±ğ›¼\alpha (or Î²ğ›½\beta) are â€œtypicalâ€. Î±ğ›¼\alpha-PrecisionÂ isÂ theÂ fractionÂ ofÂ synthetic samples that resemble the â€œmost typicalâ€ fraction Î±ğ›¼\alpha of real samples, whereas Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall is the fraction of real samples covered by the most typical fraction Î²ğ›½\beta of synthetic samples. The two metrics are evaluated for all Î±,Î²âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›¼ğ›½01\alpha,\beta\in[0,1], providing entire precision and recall curves instead of single numbers. To compute both metrics, we embedÂ theÂ (realÂ and synthetic) data into hyperspheres with most samples concentrated around the centers, i.e., the real and generative distributions (â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}) has spherical-shaped supports. In this transformed space, typical samples would be located near the centers of the spheres, whereas outliers would be closer to the boundaries as illustrated in Figure 1.

IfÂ oneÂ thinksÂ ofÂ standardÂ precision and recall asÂ â€œhardâ€Â binary classifiers of real and synthetic data,Â ourÂ proposedÂ metrics can be thought of as soft-boundary classifiers that do not only compare the supports of â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}, but also assesses whether both distributions are calibrated. Precision and recall metrics are special cases of Î±ğ›¼\alpha-Precision and Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall for Î±=Î²=1ğ›¼ğ›½1\alpha=\beta=1. As we show later, our new metric definitions solve many of the drawbacks of standard precision-recall analysis, such as lack of robustness to outliers and failure to detect distributional mismatches (Naeem etÂ al., 2020). They also enable detailed diagnostics of different types of model failure, such as mode collapse and mode invention. Moreover, optimal values of our metrics are achieved only when â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} are identical, thereby eliminating theÂ needÂ toÂ augment the model evaluation procedure with additional measures of statisticalÂ divergenceÂ (e.g., KL divergence, FrÃ©chet distance (Heusel etÂ al., 2017), and maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) (Sutherland etÂ al., 2016)). A detailedÂ surveyÂ of existing evaluation metrics is provided in the Appendix.

Previous works relied on pre-trained embeddings (e.g., ImageNet feature extractors (Deng etÂ al., 2009). In this work, we utilize (hyperspheric) feature embeddings that are model- and domain-agnostic, and are tailored to our metric definitions. These embeddings can be completely bespoke to raw data or applied to pre-trained embeddings. This enables our metric to remain operable in application domains where no pre-trained representations are available.

Overfitting is a crucial mode of failure of generative models, especially when modeling sensitive dataÂ withÂ privacy requirements (Yoon etÂ al., 2020), but it has beenÂ overlookedÂ in previous work which focused exclusively on assessing fidelity and diversity (Brock etÂ al., 2018). As we show in our experiments (Section 5), by accounting for generalization performance, our metric provide a fuller picture of the quality of synthetic data. Precisely, we show thatÂ someÂ ofÂ theÂ celebrated generative models score highly for fidelity and diversity simply because they memorize real samples, rendering them inadequate for privacy-sensitive applications.

Model auditing as a novel use case.Â TheÂ sample-levelÂ nature of our metrics inspires the new use case of model auditing, where we judge individual synthetic samples by their quality, and reject samples that have low fidelityÂ orÂ areÂ unauthentic. In Section 5, we show that model audits can improve model outputs in a post-hoc fashion without any modifications to the model itself, and demonstrate this use case in synthesizing clinical data for COVID-19 patients.

2.1 What makes a good synthetic data set?

Our goal is to construct a metric ğ“”â€‹(ğ’Ÿrâ€‹eâ€‹aâ€‹l,ğ’Ÿsâ€‹yâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹h)ğ“”subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}}(\mathcal{D}_{real},\mathcal{D}_{synth}) for the quality of ğ’Ÿsâ€‹yâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹hsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„\mathcal{D}_{synth}Â inÂ orderÂ to (i) evaluate the performance of the underlying generative model, and (ii) audit the model outputsÂ byÂ discarding low-quality samples, thereby improving the overall quality of ğ’Ÿsâ€‹yâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹hsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„\mathcal{D}_{synth}. In order for ğ“”ğ“”\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}} to fulfill the evaluation and auditing tasks, it must satisfy the following desiderata: (1) it should be able to disentangle the different modes of failure of â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} through interpretable measures of performance, and (2) it should be sample-wise computable, i.e., we should be able to tell if a given (individual) synthetic sample Xgâˆ¼â„™gsimilar-tosubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘”subscriptâ„™ğ‘”X_{g}\sim\mathbb{P}_{g} is of a low quality.

Having outlined the desiderata for our sought-after evaluation metric, we identify three independentÂ qualitiesÂ ofÂ synthetic data that the metric ğ“”ğ“”\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}} should be able to quantify.

  1. 1.

    Fidelityâ€”the generated samples resemble real samples from â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r}. A high-fidelity synthetic data set should contain â€œrealisticâ€ samples, e.g. visually-realistic images.

  2. 2.

    Diversityâ€”the generated samples are diverse enough to cover the variability of real data, i.e., a model should be able to generate a wide variety of good samples.

  3. 3.

    Generalizationâ€”the generated samples should not be mere copies of the (real) samples in training data, i.e., models that overfit to ğ’Ÿrâ€‹eâ€‹aâ€‹lsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™\mathcal{D}_{real} are not truly â€œgenerativeâ€.

In Section 3, we propose a three-dimensional evaluation metric ğ“”ğ“”\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}} that captures all of the qualities above. Our proposed metric can be succinctly described as follows:

ğ“”â‰œ(Î±-PrecisionâŸFâ€‹iâ€‹dâ€‹eâ€‹lâ€‹iâ€‹tâ€‹y,Î²-RecallâŸDâ€‹iâ€‹vâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹sâ€‹iâ€‹tâ€‹y,AuthenticityâŸGâ€‹eâ€‹nâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹aâ€‹lâ€‹iâ€‹zâ€‹aâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹oâ€‹n).â‰œğ“”subscriptâŸÎ±-Precisionğ¹ğ‘–ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦subscriptâŸÎ²-Recallğ·ğ‘–ğ‘£ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘ ğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘¦subscriptâŸAuthenticityğºğ‘’ğ‘›ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘§ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘œğ‘›\displaystyle\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}}\triangleq(\underbrace{\mbox{$\alpha$-Precision}}_{Fidelity},\,\,\underbrace{\mbox{$\beta$-Recall}}_{Diversity},\,\,\underbrace{\mbox{Authenticity}}_{Generalization}). (1)

The Î±ğ›¼\alpha-Precision and Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall metrics are generalizations of the conventional notions of precision and recall used in binary classification analysis (Flach & Kull, 2015). Precision measures the rate by which the model synthesizes â€œrealistic-lookingâ€ samples, whereas the recall measuresÂ theÂ fraction of real samples that are covered by â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}. AuthenticityÂ measures the fraction of synthetic samples that are invented by the model and not copied from the training data.

2.2 Evaluation and Auditing pipelines

We now briefly summarize the steps involved inÂ theÂ evaluation and auditing tasks. Since statistical comparisonsÂ ofÂ complex data types in the raw input space ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} are difficult, the evaluation pipeline starts by embedding Xrsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘ŸX_{r} andÂ Xgsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘”X_{g}Â intoÂ a meaningful feature space through an evaluation embedding Î¦Î¦\Phi, and evaluating ğ“”ğ“”\boldsymbol{\mathcal{E}} on the embedded features (Figure 2(a)). In Section 4, we show that the definitions ofÂ Î±ğ›¼\alpha-PrecisionÂ and Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall based on the notion of minimum volume sets inspire a natural construction for the representation Î¦Î¦\Phi.

In the post-hoc model auditing task, weÂ computeÂ theÂ sample-level metrics for each Xg,jsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘”ğ‘—X_{g,j} in ğ’Ÿsâ€‹yâ€‹nâ€‹tâ€‹hsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ ğ‘¦ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„\mathcal{D}_{synth}, and discard samples with low authenticity and/or precision scores, which results in a â€œcuratedâ€ synthetic data set with an improved overall performance. When granted direct access to the model â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}, the auditor acts as a rejection sampler that repeatedly draws samples from â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}, only accepting ones with high precision and authenticity (Figure 2(b)). ModelÂ auditingÂ isÂ possible through our metrics as they can be used toÂ evaluateÂ the quality of individual synthetic samples; the same task cannot be carried out with statistical divergenceÂ measuresÂ thatÂ compare the overall real and generative distributions.

3.2 Sample-level evaluation metrics

3.2.1 Î±ğ›¼\alpha-Precision and Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall

ğœ¶ğœ¶\boldsymbol{\alpha}-Precision. The conventional Precision metric is defined as the probability that a generated sample isÂ supportedÂ byÂ the real distribution, i.e. â„™â€‹(X~gâˆˆğ’®r)â„™subscript~ğ‘‹ğ‘”subscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{X}_{g}\in\mathcal{S}_{r}) (Sajjadi etÂ al., 2018). We propose a more refined measure of sampleÂ fidelity,Â calledÂ the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-Precision metric (PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha}), which we define as follows:

PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼\displaystyle P_{\alpha}\,\, â‰œâ„™â€‹(X~gâˆˆğ’®rÎ±),forÂ Î±âˆˆ[0,1].â‰œabsentâ„™subscript~ğ‘‹ğ‘”subscriptsuperscriptğ’®ğ›¼ğ‘ŸforÂ Î±âˆˆ[0,1].\displaystyle\triangleq\,\,\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{X}_{g}\in\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r}),\,\mbox{for $\alpha\in[0,1]$.} (4)

That is, PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} isÂ theÂ probabilityÂ that a synthetic sample resides in the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-support of the real distribution.

ğœ·ğœ·\boldsymbol{\beta}-Recall. To assess diversity in synthetic data, we propose the Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall metric as a generalization of the conventional Recall metric. Formally, we define the Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall as follows:

RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½\displaystyle R_{\beta}\,\, â‰œâ„™â€‹(X~râˆˆğ’®gÎ²),forÂ Î²âˆˆ[0,1],â‰œabsentâ„™subscript~ğ‘‹ğ‘Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ’®ğ›½ğ‘”forÂ Î²âˆˆ[0,1],\displaystyle\triangleq\,\,\mathbb{P}(\widetilde{X}_{r}\in\mathcal{S}^{\beta}_{g}),\,\mbox{for $\beta\in[0,1]$,} (5)

i.e., RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} is the fraction of real samples that reside within the Î²ğ›½\beta-support of the generative distribution.

Interpreting Î±ğ›¼\boldsymbol{\alpha}-Precision and Î²ğ›½\boldsymbol{\beta}-Recall. To interpret (4) and (5), we revisit the notion of Î±ğ›¼\alpha-support. From (2), we know that an Î±ğ›¼\alpha-support hosts the most densely packed probability mass Î±ğ›¼\alpha in a distribution, hence ğ’®rÎ±subscriptsuperscriptğ’®ğ›¼ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r} and ğ’®gÎ²subscriptsuperscriptğ’®ğ›½ğ‘”\mathcal{S}^{\beta}_{g} always concentrate around the modes of â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} (Figure 3); samples residing outside of ğ’®rÎ±subscriptsuperscriptğ’®ğ›¼ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{S}^{\alpha}_{r} and ğ’®gÎ²subscriptsuperscriptğ’®ğ›½ğ‘”\mathcal{S}^{\beta}_{g} can be thought of as outliers. In this sense, PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} do not count outliers when assessing fidelity and diversity. That is, the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-Precision score deems a synthetic sample to be of a high fidelity not only if it looks â€œrealisticâ€, but also if it looks â€œtypicalâ€. Similarly, Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall counts a real sample as being covered by â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} only if it is not an outlier in â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}. By sweeping the values of Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta from 0 to 1, we obtain a varying definition of which samples are typical and which are outliersâ€”this gives us entire PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} curves as illustrated in Figure 3.

Generalizing precision-recall analysis. Unlike standard precision and recall, PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} take into account not only the supports of â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}, but also their densities. Standard precision-recall are single points on the PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} curves; they coincide with PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} evaluated on full supports (P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} and R1subscriptğ‘…1R_{1}). By defining our metrics withÂ respectÂ toÂ Î±ğ›¼\alpha- and Î²ğ›½\beta-supports, we do not treat all samples equally,Â butÂ assign higher importance to samples in â€œdenserâ€ regions in ğ’®rsubscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{S}_{r} and ğ’®gsubscriptğ’®ğ‘”\mathcal{S}_{g}. PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} reflect the extent to whichÂ â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r}Â andÂ â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} are calibratedâ€”i.e., good PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} are achieved when â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} share the same modes and not just a common support.

The proposed PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} metrics address major shortcomings of the commonly used P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} and R1subscriptğ‘…1R_{1}, among these are: lack of robustness to outliers, failure to detect matching distributions, and inability to diagnose different types of distributional failure (Naeem etÂ al., 2020). Basically,Â â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}Â will score perfectly on precision and recall (R1subscriptğ‘…1R_{1}=P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1}=1) as long as it nails the support of â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r}, even if â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} place totally different densities on their common support. Figure 3 illustrates how our metrics remedy these shortcomings. While optimal R1subscriptğ‘…1R_{1} and P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} are achieved by arbitrarily mismatched densities, our PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} curves are optimized only when â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} are identical as stated by Theorem 1.

Theorem 1. The Î±ğ›¼\alpha-Precision and Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall satisfy the condition PÎ±/Î±=RÎ²/Î²=1,âˆ€Î±,Î²,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼ğ›¼subscriptğ‘…ğ›½ğ›½1for-allğ›¼ğ›½P_{\alpha}/\alpha=R_{\beta}/\beta=1,\,\forall\,\alpha,\beta, iff the generative and real densities are equal, i.e., â„™g=â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”subscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{g}=\mathbb{P}_{r}.â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â€‰â– â– \blacksquare

Theorem 1 says that a model is optimal if and onlyÂ ifÂ bothÂ its PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} are straight lines with unityÂ slopes.Â ItÂ alsoÂ implies that our metrics are not maximized if â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} have different densities, even if they share the same support.

Measuring statistical discrepancy with PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼\boldsymbol{P_{\alpha}} & RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½\boldsymbol{R_{\beta}}. While the PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} curves provide a detailed view on a modelâ€™s fidelity and diversity, it is often more convenient to summarize performance in a single number. To this end, we define the mean absolute deviation of PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} as:

Î”â€‹PÎ±=âˆ«01|PÎ±âˆ’Î±|â€‹ğ‘‘Î±,Î”â€‹RÎ²=âˆ«01|RÎ²âˆ’Î²|â€‹ğ‘‘Î²,formulae-sequenceÎ”subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼superscriptsubscript01subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼ğ›¼differential-dğ›¼Î”subscriptğ‘…ğ›½superscriptsubscript01subscriptğ‘…ğ›½ğ›½differential-dğ›½\displaystyle\Delta P_{\alpha}=\int_{0}^{1}|P_{\alpha}-\alpha|\,d\alpha,\,\,\Delta R_{\beta}=\int_{0}^{1}|R_{\beta}-\beta|\,d\beta, (6)

where Î”â€‹PÎ±âˆˆ[0,1/2]Î”subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼012\Delta P_{\alpha}\in[0,1/2] and Î”â€‹RÎ²âˆˆ[0,1/2]Î”subscriptğ‘…ğ›½012\Delta R_{\beta}\in[0,1/2] quantify the extent to which PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} deviate from their optimal values. We define the integrated PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} metrics as Iâ€‹PÎ±=1âˆ’2â€‹Î”â€‹PÎ±ğ¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼12Î”subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼IP_{\alpha}=1-2\Delta P_{\alpha} and Iâ€‹RÎ²=1âˆ’2â€‹Î”â€‹RÎ²ğ¼subscriptğ‘…ğ›½12Î”subscriptğ‘…ğ›½IR_{\beta}=1-2\Delta R_{\beta}, both take values in [0,1]01[0,1]. From Theorem 1, Iâ€‹PÎ±=Iâ€‹RÎ²=1ğ¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼ğ¼subscriptğ‘…ğ›½1IP_{\alpha}=IR_{\beta}=1 only if â„™g=â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”subscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{g}=\mathbb{P}_{r}.

Together, Iâ€‹PÎ±ğ¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼IP_{\alpha} and Iâ€‹RÎ²ğ¼subscriptğ‘…ğ›½IR_{\beta} serve as measures of the discrepancy between â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}, eliminating the need to augment our precision-recall analysis with measures ofÂ statisticalÂ divergence. Moreover, unlike fğ‘“f-divergenceÂ measuresÂ (e.g.,Â KL divergence), the (Iâ€‹PÎ±,Iâ€‹RÎ²ğ¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼ğ¼subscriptğ‘…ğ›½IP_{\alpha},IR_{\beta}) metric disentangles fidelity and diversity into separate components, and its computation does not require that â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} share a common support.

3.2.2 Authenticity

Generalization is independent of precision and recall since a model can achieve perfect fidelity and diversity without truly generating any samples, simply by resampling training data. Unlike discriminative models for which generalization is easily tested via held-out data, evaluating generalization in generative models is not straightforward (Adlam etÂ al., 2019; Meehan etÂ al., 2020). We propose an authenticityÂ scoreÂ Aâˆˆ[0,1]ğ´01A\in[0,1] to quantify the rate by which a model generates new samples. To pin down a mathematical definition for Ağ´A, we reformulate â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} as a mixture of densities as follows:

â„™g=Aâ‹…â„™gâ€²+(1âˆ’A)â‹…Î´g,Ïµ,subscriptâ„™ğ‘”â‹…ğ´subscriptsuperscriptâ„™â€²ğ‘”â‹…1ğ´subscriptğ›¿ğ‘”italic-Ïµ\displaystyle\mathbb{P}_{g}=A\cdot\mathbb{P}^{\prime}_{g}+(1-A)\cdot\delta_{g,\epsilon}, (7)

where â„™gâ€²subscriptsuperscriptâ„™â€²ğ‘”\mathbb{P}^{\prime}_{g} is the generative distribution conditionedÂ onÂ the synthetic samples not being copied, and Î´g,Ïµsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘”italic-Ïµ\delta_{g,\epsilon} is a noisy distribution over training data. In particular, we define Î´g,Ïµsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘”italic-Ïµ\delta_{g,\epsilon} as Î´g,Ïµ=Î´gâˆ—ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïµ2)subscriptğ›¿ğ‘”italic-Ïµâˆ—subscriptğ›¿ğ‘”ğ’©0superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\delta_{g,\epsilon}=\delta_{g}\ast\mathcal{N}(0,\epsilon^{2}), where Î´gsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘”\delta_{g} is a discrete distribution that places an unknown probability mass on each training data point in ğ’Ÿrâ€‹eâ€‹aâ€‹lsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘™\mathcal{D}_{real}, Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is an arbitrarily small noise variance, and âˆ—âˆ—\ast is the convolution operator. Essentially, (7) assumes that the model flips a (biased coin), pulling off a training sample with probability 1âˆ’A1ğ´1-A and adding some noise to it, or innovating a new sample with probability Ağ´A.

To address this challenge, we pre-processÂ theÂ realÂ andÂ synthetic data in a way that renders estimation of Î±ğ›¼\alpha-and Î²ğ›½\beta-supports straightforward. Authenticity classifier. We derive the classifier fAsubscriptğ‘“ğ´f_{A} from a hypothesis test that tests if a sample X~g,jsubscript~ğ‘‹ğ‘”ğ‘—\widetilde{X}_{g,j} is non-memorized. Intuitively, fAsubscriptğ‘“ğ´f_{A} deems sample jğ‘—j unauthentic if it is closer to iâˆ—superscriptğ‘–i^{*} than any other real sample in the training data.

5 Experiments and Use Cases

5.1 Evaluating & auditing generative models for synthesizing COVID-19 data

In this experiment, we use our metric to assess the ability of different generative models to synthesize COVID-19 patient data that can be used for predictive modeling. Using SIVEP-Gripe (SIVEP-Gripe, 2020), a database of 99,557 COVID patients in Brazil, including sensitive data such as ethnicity. We use generative models to synthesize replicas of this data and fit predictive models to the replicas.

Models and baselines. We create 4 synthetic data sets using GAN, VAE, Wasserstein GANsÂ withÂ a gradient penalty (WGAN-GP) (Gulrajani etÂ al., 2017), and ADS-GAN, which is specifically designed to prevent patient identifiablity in generated data (Yoon etÂ al., 2020).Â ToÂ evaluateÂ these synthetic data sets, we use FrÃ©chet Inception Distance (FID) (Heusel etÂ al., 2017), Precision/Recall (P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1}/R1subscriptğ‘…1R_{1}) (Sajjadi etÂ al., 2018), Density/Coverage (Dğ·D/Cğ¶C) (Naeem etÂ al., 2020), Parzen window likelihood (Pâ€‹Wğ‘ƒğ‘ŠPW) (Bengio etÂ al., 2013) and Wasserstein distance (Wğ‘ŠW) as baselines. On each synthetic data set, we fit a (predictive) Logistic regression model to predict patient-level COVID-19 mortality.

Predictive modeling with synthetic data.Â InÂ theÂ contextÂ of predictive modeling, a generative model is assessed with respect to its usefulness in training predictive models that generalize well on real data. Hence, the â€œground-truthâ€ ranking of the 4 generative models corresponds to the ranking of the AUC-ROC scores achieved by predictive models fit to their respective synthetic data sets and tested on real data (Figure 4(a)). The data synthesized by ADS-GAN (Ã—\boldsymbol{\times}) displayed the best performance, followed by WGAN-GP (âˆ™âˆ™\bullet), VAE (â–²â–²\blacktriangle), and GAN (â– â– \blacksquare). To assess the accuracy of baseline evaluation metrics, we test if each metricÂ canÂ recoverÂ the ground-truth ranking of the 4 generative modelsÂ (FigureÂ 4(a)). Our integrated precision and recall metrics Iâ€‹PÎ±ğ¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼IP_{\alpha} and Iâ€‹RÎ²ğ¼subscriptğ‘…ğ›½IR_{\beta} both assign the highest scores to ADS-GAN; Iâ€‹PÎ±ğ¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼IP_{\alpha}Â exactlyÂ nailsÂ the right ranking of generative models. On the other hand, competing metrics such as P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1}, Cğ¶C and Dğ·D, over-estimate the quality of VAE and WGAN-GPâ€”if we use these metrics to decide which generative model to use, we will end up with predictive models that perform poorly, i.e. AUC-ROC of the predictive model fitted to synthetic data with best P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} is 0.55, compared to an AUC-ROC of 0.79 for our Iâ€‹PÎ±ğ¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼IP_{\alpha} score.

These results highlight the importanceÂ ofÂ accountingÂ forÂ the densities â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} and â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r}, and not just their supports, when evaluating generative models. This is because a shifted â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} would result in a â€œcovariate shiftâ€ in synthetic data, leading to poor generalization for predictive models fitted to it, even when real and synthetic supports coincide.Â AsÂ shownÂ inÂ Figure 4(a), metrics that compare distributions (our metrics, Pâ€‹Wğ‘ƒğ‘ŠPW and Fâ€‹Iâ€‹Dğ¹ğ¼ğ·FID), accurately rank the 4 generative models.

Hyper-parameter tuningÂ & theÂ privacy-utilityÂ tradeoff. Another use case for our metric is hyper-parameter optimization for generative models. Here, we focus on the best-performing modelÂ inÂ our previous experiment: ADS-GAN. This model has a hyper-parameter Î»âˆˆâ„ğœ†â„\lambda\in\mathbb{R} that determines the importance of the privacy-preservation loss function used to regularize the training of ADS-GAN (Yoon etÂ al., 2020): smaller values of Î»ğœ†\lambda make the model more prone to overfitting, and hence privacy leakage. Figure 4(b) shows how our precision and authenticity metrics change with the different values of Î»ğœ†\lambda: the curve provides an interpretable tradeoff between privacy and utility (e.g., for Î»=2ğœ†2\lambda=2, an Ağ´A score of 0.4 means that 60%percent\% of patients may have personal information exposed). Increasing Î»ğœ†\lambda improves privacy at the expense of precision. By visualizing this tradeoff using our metric, data holders can understand the risks of different modeling choices involved in data synthesis.

Improving synthetic data via model auditing. Our metrics are not only useful for hyper-parameter tuning, but can also be used to improve the quality of synthetic data generated by an already-trained model using (post-hoc) auditing. Because our metrics are defined on the sample level,Â weÂ canÂ discardÂ unauthentic or imprecise samples. This does not only lead to nearly optimalÂ precisionÂ andÂ authenticity for the curated data (Figure 4(c)), but also improves the AUC-ROC of the predictive model fitted to audited data (from 0.76 to 0.78 for the audited ADS-GAN synthetic data, p<0.005ğ‘0.005p<0.005), since auditing eliminates noisy data points that would otherwise undermine generalization performance.

5.2 Diagnosing generative distributions of MNIST

In this experiment, we test the ability of our metrics to detect common modes of failure in generative modelingâ€”in particular, we emulate a mode dropping scenario, where the generative model fails to recognize the distinct modes in a multimodal distribution â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r}, and instead recovers a single mode in â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}. To construct this scenario, we fit a conditional GAN (CGAN) model (Wang etÂ al., 2018) on the MNIST data set, and generate 1,000 samples for each of the digits 0-9. (We can think of each digit as a distinct mode in â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r}.) To apply mode dropping, we first sample 1,000 instances of each digit from the CGAN, and then delete individual samples of digits 1 to 9 with a probability Pdâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹psubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘P_{drop}, and replace the deleted samples with new samples ofÂ theÂ digitÂ 0Â toÂ complete a data set of 10,000 instances. The parameter Pdâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹pâˆˆ[0,1]subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘01P_{drop}\in[0,1] determines the severity of mode dropping: for Pdâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹p=0subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘0P_{drop}=0, the data set has all digits equally representedÂ withÂ 1,000Â samples, and for Pdâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹p=1subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘1P_{drop}=1, the data set has 10,000 samples of the digit 0 only as depicted in Figure 5(a) (bottom panel).

We show how the different evaluation metrics respond to varying Pdâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹psubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘P_{drop} from 0 to 1 in Figure 5(a) (top). Because mode dropping pushes the generative distribution away from the real one, statistical distance metrics such as Wğ‘ŠW and Fâ€‹Iâ€‹Dğ¹ğ¼ğ·FID increase as Pdâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹psubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘P_{drop} approaches 1. However, these metrics only reflect a discrepancy between â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}, and do not disentangle the Fidelity and Diversity components of this discrepancy. On the other hand, standard precision and recall metric are completely insensitive to mode dropping except for the extreme case when Pdâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹p=1subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘1P_{drop}=1. This is because both metrics only check supports of â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}, so they cannot recognize mode dropping as long as there is a non-zero probability that the model will generates digits 1-9. On the contrary, mode dropping reflects in our metrics, which manifest in a decliningÂ Iâ€‹RÎ²ğ¼subscriptğ‘…ğ›½IR_{\beta} as Pdâ€‹râ€‹oâ€‹psubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘œğ‘P_{drop} increases. Since mode dropping affects coverage of digits and not the quality of images, it only affects Iâ€‹RÎ²ğ¼subscriptğ‘…ğ›½IR_{\beta} but not Iâ€‹PÎ±ğ¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼IP_{\alpha}.

5.3 Revisiting the Hide-and-Seek challenge for synthesizing time-series data

Finally, we use our metric to re-evaluate the generative models submitted to the NeurIPS 2020 Hide-and-Seek competition (Jordon etÂ al., 2020). In this competition, participants were required to synthesize intensive care time-series data based on real data from the AmsterdamUMCdb database. A total of 16 submissions were judged based on the accuracy of predictive models fit to the synthetic data (an approach similar to the one in Section 5.1). The submissions followed various modeling choices, including recurrent GANs, autoencoders, differential privacy GANs, etc. Details of all submissions are available online. Surprisingly, the winning submission was a very simplistic model that adds Gaussian noise to the real data to create new samples.

To evaluate our metrics on time-series data, we trained a Seq-2-Seq embedding that is augmented with our One-class representations to transform time-series into fixed feature vectors. (The architecture for this embedding is provided in the Supplementary material.) In Figure 5(b), we evaluate all submissions with respect to precision, recall and authenticity. As we can see, the winning submission comes out as one of the least authentic models, despite performing competitively in terms of precision and recall. This highlights the detrimental impact of using naÃ¯ve metrics for evaluating generative modelsâ€”based on the competition results, clinical institutions seeking to create synthetic data sets may be led to believe that Submission 1 in Figure 5(b) is the right model to use. However, our metricsâ€”which give a fuller picture of the true quality of all submissionsâ€”shows that such model creates unauthentic samples that are mere noisy copies of real data, which would pose risk to patient privacy. We hope that our metrics and our pre-trained Seq-2-Seq embeddings can help clinical institutions evaluate the quality of their synthetic time-series data in the future.

5.4 Image generation benchmarks

Finally, we use our metrics to evaluate the performance of two state-of-the-art image generation baselines:Â StyleGAN and diffusion probabilistic models.Â Particularly,Â weÂ compare StyleGAN2-ADA (Karras etÂ al., 2020)Â withÂ denoisingÂ diffusion probabilistic models (DDPM) (Ho etÂ al., 2020). We generate 10,000 samples from StyleGAN2-ADA and DDPM models pre-trained on the CIFAR-10 data set, and evaluate the Iâ€‹PÎ±ğ¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼IP_{\alpha} and Iâ€‹RÎ²ğ¼subscriptğ‘…ğ›½IR_{\beta} metrics for both samples with respect to ground-truth samples in the original CIFAR-10Â data. The Î±ğ›¼\alpha- and Î²ğ›½\beta-supports were evaluated on feature embeddings obtained using the pretrained Inception v3 model.

While the FID metric ranks StyleGAN2-ADA higher than DDPM, our metrics paint a more nuanced picture for the comparison between both models. We found that DDPM captures the distribution of the data better in region where the supports of the two models overlap, as evident by the superior Iâ€‹PÎ±ğ¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼IP_{\alpha} of DDPM. On the other hand, StyleGAN scores higher in the recall metric, indicating a better capturing of the diversity of images.

Implementation of our metric and code for all experiments is provided in github.com/ahmedmalaa/evaluating-generative-models and https://github.com/vanderschaarlab/evaluating-generative-models.

6 Conclusions

In this paper, we introduced a novel evaluation metric that characterizes the fidelity, diversity and generalization performance of generative models. Our metricÂ isÂ groundedÂ inÂ the notion of minimum volume sets, and enables both sample-level and distribution-level evaluation of the quality ofÂ aÂ synthetic sample. We have demonstrated through several experiments that our evaluation metric is applicableÂ toÂ aÂ wideÂ variety of use cases and application domains.

We believe that the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-Precision, Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall and authenticity metrics are particularly useful in clinical applications where both the accuracy of synthetic data distribution and the quality of individual samples are of great interest. The distinction between typical and outlier samples makesÂ ourÂ precision and recall analysis well-suited for evaluating fairness of synthetic data, i.e., how well it represents patient subgroups. We leave the in-depth study of this use case for future work.

Appendix A: Literature Review

In this Section, we provide a comprehensive survey of prior work, along with a detailed discussion on how our metric relates to existing ones. We classify existingÂ metricsÂ forÂ evaluating generative models into two main classes:

  1. 1.

    Statistical divergence metrics

  2. 2.

    Precision and recall metrics

Divergence metrics are single-valued measures of the distance between the real and generative distributions, whereas precision-recall metrics classify real and generated samples as to whether they are covered by generative and real distributions, respectively. In what follows, we list examples of these two types of metrics, highlighting their limitations.

Statistical divergence metrics.

The most straightforward approach for evaluating a generative distribution is to compute the model log-likelihoodâ€”for density estimation tasks, this has been the de-facto standard for training and evaluating generative models. However, the likelihood function is a model-dependent criteria: this is problematic because the likelihood of many state-of-the-art models is inaccessible. For instance, GANs are implicit likelihood models and hence provide no explicit expression for its achieved log-likelihood (Goodfellow etÂ al., 2014). Other models, energy-based models has a normalization constant in the likelihood expression that is generally difficult to compute as they require solving intractable complex integrals (Kingma & Welling, 2013).

Statistical divergence measures are alternative (model-independent) metrics that are related to log-likelihood, and are commonly used for training and evaluating generative models. Examples include lower bounds on the log-likelihood (Kingma & Welling, 2013), contrastive divergence and noise contrastive estimation (Hinton, 2002; Gutmann & HyvÃ¤rinen, 2010), probability flow (Sohl-Dickstein etÂ al., 2011), score matching (HyvÃ¤rinen etÂ al., 2009), maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) (Gretton etÂ al., 2012), and the Jensen-Shannon divergence (JSD).

In general, statistical divergence measures suffer from the following limitations. The first limitation is that likelihood-based measures can be inadequate in high-dimensional feature spaces. As has been shown in (Theis etÂ al., 2015), one can construct scenarios with poor likelihood and great samples through a simple lookup table model, and vice versa, we can think of scenarios with great likelihood and poor samples. This is because, if the model samples white noise 99% of the time, and samples high-quality outputs 1% of the time, the log-likelihood will be hardly distinguishable from a model that samples high-quality outputs 100% of the time if the data dimension is large. Our metrics solve this problem by measuring the rate of error on a sample-level rather than evaluating the overall distribution of samples.

Moreover, statistical divergence measures collapse the different modes of failure of the generative distribution into a single number. This hinders our ability to diagnose the different modes of generative model failures such as mode dropping, mode collapse, poor coverage, etc.

Precision and recall metrics.

Precision and recall metrics for evaluating generative models were originally proposed in (Sajjadi etÂ al., 2018). Our metrics differ from these metrics in various ways. First, unlike standard metrics, Î±ğ›¼\alpha-Precision and Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall take into account not only the supports of â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}, but also the actual probability densities of both distributions. Standard precision (and recall) correspond to one point on the PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} (and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta}) curve; they are equal to PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} evaluated on the full support (i.e., P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} and R1subscriptğ‘…1R_{1}). By defining our metrics with respect to the Î±ğ›¼\alpha- and Î²ğ›½\beta-supports, we do not treat all samples equally, but rather assign higher importance to samples that land in â€œdenserâ€ regions of ğ’®rsubscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{S}_{r} and ğ’®gsubscriptğ’®ğ‘”\mathcal{S}_{g}. Hence, PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} reflect the extent to which â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} are calibratedâ€”i.e., good PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} curves are achieved when â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} share the same modes and not just a common support. While optimal R1subscriptğ‘…1R_{1} and P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} can be achieved by arbitrarilyÂ mismatched â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g}, our PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} curves are optimized only when â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} are identical as stated by Theorem 1.

The new PÎ±subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼P_{\alpha} and RÎ²subscriptğ‘…ğ›½R_{\beta} metrics address the major shortcomings of precision and recall. Among these shortcomings are: lack of robustness to outliers, failure to detect matching distributions, and inability to diagnose different types of distributional failure (such as mode collapse, mode invention, or density shifts) (Naeem etÂ al., 2020). Basically, a model â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} will score perfectly on precision and recall (R1subscriptğ‘…1R_{1}=P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1}=1) as long as it nails the support of â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r}, even if â„™rsubscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{P}_{r} and â„™gsubscriptâ„™ğ‘”\mathbb{P}_{g} place totally different densities on their common support.

In addition to the above, our metrics estimate the supports of real and generative distributions using neural networks rather than nearest neighbor estimates as in (Naeem etÂ al., 2020). This prevents our estimates from overestimating the supports of real and generative distributions, thereby overestimating the coverage or quality of the generated samples.

Appendix B: Proof of Theorem 1

To prove the statement of the Theorem, weÂ needÂ toÂ proveÂ the two following statements:

(1) â„™g=â„™râ†’PÎ±/Î±=RÎ²/Î²=1,âˆ€Î±,Î²formulae-sequencesubscriptâ„™ğ‘”subscriptâ„™ğ‘Ÿâ†’subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼ğ›¼subscriptğ‘…ğ›½ğ›½1for-allğ›¼ğ›½\mathbb{P}_{g}=\mathbb{P}_{r}\,\,\rightarrow\,\,P_{\alpha}/\alpha=R_{\beta}/\beta=1,\,\forall\alpha,\beta

Appendix C: Alternative approach for estimating the support of synthetic data & code snippets

Instead of using a kğ‘˜k-NN approach to estimate the generative support ğ’®gÎ²superscriptsubscriptğ’®ğ‘”ğ›½\mathcal{S}_{g}^{\beta}, one could use a separate one-class representation Î¦gsubscriptÎ¦ğ‘”\Phi_{g} for each new synthetic sample being evaluated. We provide code snippets and comparisons between the two approaches in the an anonymized Colab notebook. While the two approaches perform rather similarly, we opt to adopt the kğ‘˜k-NN based approach to avoid potential biases induced by using a separate representation for each generative model when using our metric for model comparisons.

Appendix D: Experimental details

.1 Data

In this research the argue for the versatility of our metrics, hence we have included results for tabular (static), time-series and image data (see Table 2). For the tabular data we use (Baqui etÂ al., 2020)â€™s preprocessed version of the SIVEP-GRIPE dataset of Brazilian ICU Covid-19 patient data. For the image experiments, we use the 10,000 samples in the default MNIST test set (LeCun, 1998). For proper evaluation of the authenticity metric, the same original data is used for training of generative models and evaluation of all metrics.

For the time-series experiments, AmsterdamUMCdb is used in a manner exactly analogous to the NeurIPS 2020 Hide-and-Seek Privacy Challenge (Jordon etÂ al., 2020), which describes it as follows: â€œAmsterdamUMCdb was developed and released by Amsterdam UMC in the Netherlands and the European Society of Intensive Care Medicine (ESICM). It is the first freely accessible comprehensive and high resolution European intensive care database. It is also first to have addressed compliance with General Data Protection Regulation [â€¦] AmsterdamUMCdb contains approximately 1 billion clinical data points related to 23,106 admissions of 20,109 unique patients between 2003 and 2016. The released data points include patient monitor and life support device data, laboratory measurements, clinical observations and scores, medical procedures and tasks, medication, fluid balance, diagnosis groups and clinical patient outcomes.â€. Notably, only the longitudinal features from this database are kept, with static ones discarded. The same subset as was used in the competition for â€œhiderâ€ synthetic data generation is used; this consists of 7695 examples with 70 features (and a time column), sequence length is limited to 100 (the original data contains sequences of up to length 135,337). The features are normalised to [0,1]01[0,1] and imputed as follows: (1) back-fill, (2) forward-fill, (3) feature median imputation. This preprocessing is chosen to match the competition (Jordon etÂ al., 2020). The competition â€œhiderâ€ submissions were trained on this dataset and the synthetic data generated.

For metric consistency and the avoidance of tedious architecture optimization for each data modality, we follow previous works (e.g. (Heusel etÂ al., 2017; Sajjadi etÂ al., 2018; KynkÃ¤Ã¤nniemi etÂ al., 2019; Naeem etÂ al., 2020)) and embed image and time series data into a static embedding. This is required, since the original space is non-euclidean and will result in failure of most metrics. The static embedding is used for computing baseline metrics, and is used as input for the One-Class embedder.

For finding static representations of MNIST, images are upscaled and embedded using InceptionV3 pre-trained on ImageNET without top layer. This is the same embedder used for computing FrÃ©chet Inception Distance (Heusel etÂ al., 2017). Very similar results were obtained using instead a VGG-16 embedder (Brock etÂ al., 2018; KynkÃ¤Ã¤nniemi etÂ al., 2019). Preliminary experimentation with random VGG-16 models (Naeem etÂ al., 2020) did not yield stable results for neither baselines nor our methods.

.2 Time series embedding

The time series embeddings used throughout this work are based on Unsupervised Learning of Video Representations using LSTMs (Srivastava etÂ al., 2015), specifically the â€œLSTM Autoencoder Modeâ€. A sequence-to-sequence LSTM network is trained, with the target sequence set as the input sequence (reversed for ease of optimization), see Figure 6. The encoder hidden and cell states (hâ„h and cğ‘c vectors) at the end of a sequence are used as the learned representation and are passed to the decoder during training. At inference, these are concatenated to obtain one fixed-length vector per example.

The specifics of the LSTM autoencoder used here are as follows. Two LSTM layers are used in each encoder and decoder. The size of h,câ„ğ‘h,c vectors is 707070 (280280280 after concatenation). The model was implemented in PyTorch (Paszke etÂ al., 2017), utilising sequence packing for computational efficiency. All autoencoders were trained to convergence on the original data; the synthetic time series data was passed through this at inference. The time column (when present in data) was discarded.

.3 Full results

Included metrics are Wasserstein distance, FrÃ©chet Distance (Fâ€‹Dğ¹ğ·FD), Parzen window likelihood estimate, precision P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1}, recall R1subscriptğ‘…1R_{1}, density (Dğ·D), coverage Cğ¶C and the proposed metrics, specifically integrated Î±ğ›¼\alpha-precision Iâ€‹PÎ±ğ¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼IP_{\alpha}, integrated Î²ğ›½\beta-recall Iâ€‹RÎ²ğ¼subscriptğ‘…ğ›½IR_{\beta} and authenticity Ağ´A . For the tabular data, data is generated using a VAE, GAN, Wasserstein GAN with gradient penalisation (WGAN-GP) (Arjovsky etÂ al., 2017), ADS-GAN (Yoon etÂ al., 2020), Differentially Private GAN (DP-GAN) (Xie etÂ al., 2018) and an ADS-GAN generated dataset in which samples are audited on precision and authenticity. Similarly, Table 4 contains metric results111Note that here, the FrÃ©chet Distance equals the FrÃ©chet Inception Distance, because the metrics are computed on InceptionV3 embeddings of the image data. for MNIST, generated by a VAE, Deep convolution GAN (DCGAN), WGAN-GP and ADS-GAN. The last row shows results for an audited version of the Hamada dataset, in which we keep generating data using the Hamada model and discard samples that do not meet the precision or authenticity threshold.

.4 Hyperparameter optimization

.4.1 Baselines

For computing the density and coverage metrics, we set a threshold of 0.95 on the minimum expected coverage, as recommended in the original work (Eq. 9 (Naeem etÂ al., 2020)). For all datasets, this is achieved for k=5ğ‘˜5k=5. For consistency in these comparisons, we use k=5ğ‘˜5k=5 for the precision and recall metrics too.

.4.2 OneClass embeddings

We use Deep SVDD (Ruff etÂ al., 2018) to embed static data into One-Class representations. To mitigate hypersphere collapse (Propostions 2 and 3 of (Ruff etÂ al., 2018)), we do not include a bias term and use ReLU activation for the One-Class embedder. Original data is split into training (80%) and validation (20%) set, and One-Class design is fine-tuned to minimise validation loss. We use the SoftBoundary objective (Eq. 3 (Ruff etÂ al., 2018)) with Î½=0.01ğœˆ0.01\nu=0.01 and center ğœ=ğŸğœ1\mathbf{c}=\mathbf{1} for tabular and time-series data and ğœ=10â‹…ğŸğœâ‹…101\mathbf{c}=10\cdot\mathbf{1} for image data. Let nhsubscriptğ‘›â„n_{h} be the number of hidden layers with each dhsubscriptğ‘‘â„d_{h} nodes, and let dzsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘§d_{z} be the dimension of the representation layer. For tabular data, we use nh=3subscriptğ‘›â„3n_{h}=3, dh=32subscriptğ‘‘â„32d_{h}=32 and dz=25subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘§25d_{z}=25; for time-series data, nh=2subscriptğ‘›â„2n_{h}=2, dh=128subscriptğ‘‘â„128d_{h}=128 and dz=32subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘§32d_{z}=32; and for MNIST nh=3subscriptğ‘›â„3n_{h}=3, dh=128subscriptğ‘‘â„128d_{h}=128 and dz=32subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘§32d_{z}=32. Models are implemented in PyTorch (Paszke etÂ al., 2017) and the AdamW optimizer is used with weight decay 10âˆ’2superscript10210^{-2}.

For the Î²ğ›½\beta-recall metric, estimating the support of synthetic data involves tuning the kğ‘˜k parameter of the kğ‘˜k-NN estimator. The kğ‘˜k parameter can be tuned by fitting the NN estimator on a portion of the data for every given kğ‘˜k, and then testing the recall on a held out (real) sample. The selected kğ‘˜k for each Î±ğ›¼\alpha is the smallest kğ‘˜k that covers Î±ğ›¼\alpha held out samples. Similar to (Naeem etÂ al., 2020), we found that through this procedure, k=5ğ‘˜5k=5 seems to come up as the optimal kğ‘˜k for most experiments.

.5 Toy experiments

We include two toy experiments that highlight the advantage of the proposed metrics compared to previous works. We focus our comparison on the improved precision and recall (KynkÃ¤Ã¤nniemi etÂ al., 2019) and density and coverage (Naeem etÂ al., 2020) metrics.

.5.1 Robustness to outliers

Naeem etÂ al. (2020) showed that the precision and recall metrics as proposed by (Sajjadi etÂ al., 2018; KynkÃ¤Ã¤nniemi etÂ al., 2019) are not robust to outliers. We replicate toy experiments to show the proposed Î±ğ›¼\alpha-Precision and Î²ğ›½\beta-Recall do not suffer the same fate.

Let X,Yâˆˆâ„dğ‘‹ğ‘Œsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘X,Y\in\mathbb{R}^{d} denote original and synthetic samples respectively, with original Xâˆ¼Nâ€‹(0,I)similar-toğ‘‹ğ‘0ğ¼X\sim N(0,I) and Yâˆ¼Nâ€‹(Î¼,I)similar-toğ‘Œğ‘ğœ‡ğ¼Y\sim N(\mu,I). We compute all metrics for Î¼âˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]ğœ‡11\mu\in[-1,1]. In this setting we conduct three experiments:

  1. 1.

    No outliers

  2. 2.

    One outlier in the real data at X=ğŸğ‘‹1X=\mathbf{1}

  3. 3.

    One outlier in the synthetic data at Y=ğŸğ‘Œ1Y=\mathbf{1}

We set d=64ğ‘‘64d=64 and both original and synthetic data we sample 100001000010000 points. Subsequent metric scores are shown in Figure

As can be seen, the precision and recall metrics are not robust to outliers, as just a single outlier has dramatic effects. The Iâ€‹PÎ±ğ¼subscriptğ‘ƒğ›¼IP_{\alpha} and Iâ€‹RÎ²ğ¼subscriptğ‘…ğ›½IR_{\beta} are not affected, as the outlier does not belong to the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-support (or Î²ğ›½\beta-support) unless Î±ğ›¼\alpha (or Î²ğ›½\beta) is large.

.5.2 Mode resolution

The precision and recall metrics only take into account the support of original and synthetic data, but not the actual densities. The density and coverage metric do take this into account, but here we show these are not able to capture this well enough to distinguish similar distributions.

In this experiment we look at mode resolution: how well is the metric able to distinguish a single mode from two modes? Let the original distribution be a mixture of two gaussians that are separated by distance Î¼ğœ‡\mu and have Ïƒ=1ğœ1\sigma=1,

Xâˆ¼12â€‹Nâ€‹(âˆ’Î¼2,1)+12â€‹Nâ€‹(+Î¼2,1)similar-toğ‘‹12ğ‘ğœ‡2112ğ‘ğœ‡21X\sim\frac{1}{2}N(-\frac{\mu}{2},1)+\frac{1}{2}N(+\frac{\mu}{2},1)

and let the synthetic data be given by

Yâˆ¼Nâ€‹(0,1+Î¼2).similar-toğ‘Œğ‘01superscriptğœ‡2Y\sim N(0,1+\mu^{2}).

This situation would arise if a synthetic data generator fails to distinguish the two nodes, and instead tries to capture the two close-by modes of the original distribution using a single mode. We compute metrics for Î¼âˆˆ[0,5]ğœ‡05\mu\in[0,5].

As can be seen, neither P&R nor D&C notice that the synthetic data only consists of a single mode, whereas the original data consisted of two. The Î±ğ›¼\alpha-precision metric is able to capture this metric: for small Î±ğ›¼\alpha the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-support of the original distribution is centred around the two separated, and does not contain the space that separates the modes (i.e. the mode of the synthetic data).
